Name: Silane, trichloro-
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Category 1 UNRTDG No. 1295, Class:  4.3(3, 8), PG I

Name: Sodium potassium alloys
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Category 1 UNRTDG No. 1422, Class:  4.3, PG I

Name: Manganese N,N'-ethylenebis(dithiocarbamate)
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 3
Rationale for classification: The subsidiary risks of the substance fall into Division 4.3, Packing Group III (UN#2210 Maneb or Maneb Preparations with not less than 60% maneb, substance which in contact with water emits flammable gases (ICSC (2003))) under the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, which corresponds to Category 3 of GHS classification. Those containing stabilizers are also classified into Division 4.3, Packing Group III (UN#2968 Maneb or Maneb Preparations (Maneb stabilized against self-heating; substance which in contact with water emits flammable gases)) under the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

Name: tricalcium diphosphide
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG Class: 4.3; PG I

Name: Diphosphorus pentasulfide
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 2
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG Class: 4.3; PG II

Name: trizinc diphosphide
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Category 1 UNRTDG No. 1714, Class:  4.3, PG I

Name: Carbon black
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Not applicable(Materials of animal or vegetable origin and mineral origin)
Rationale for classification: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

Name: Cyanamide, calcium salt (1:1)
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 3 or Not classified
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases
Rationale for classification: It reacts with water and flammable gases acetylene and ammonia are produced (HSDB, 2003). When the content of carbonized calcium (calcium carbide) which is manufacturing impurities exceeds 0.1% (UN number 1403), UNRTDG is classificationed into 4.3 and III and corresponds tocategory 3, but When other, it is outside Category.

Name: aluminium phosphide
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Category 1 UNRTDG No. 1397, Class:  4.3, PG I

Name: chlorophenol
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Not applicable (o, m, p)
Rationale for classification: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)(o, m, p-)

Name: 2-Amino-4-[hydroxy(methyl)phosphinoyl]butyric acid; Glufosinate
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Not classified (ammonium salts), Classification not possible (free acid)
Rationale for classification: Stable to water (water solubility: 500g/L or greater (ammonium salts) (Agricultural Chemical Registration Data)). As for free acid, classification is not possible due to lack of data.

Name: Aluminium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Classification not possible (Category 2 or Category 3)
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases
Rationale for classification: No data (since reaction with water changes with purity, particle form, and particle diameter, it cannot be judged which category it belongs unless a routine testing is carried out.)

Name: lithium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG Class: 4.3; PG I

Name: Magnesium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Classification not possible (Category 1, 2 or 3)
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: No data (since reaction with water changes with purity, particle form, and particle diameter, it cannot be judged which category it belongs unless a routine testing is carried out.)

Name: potassium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification:
UNRTDG Class: 4.3; PG I 
Evolves hydrogen and ignites on contact with water. (NFPA (12th, 1997) p49-109)

Name: Sodium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification:
It is classified into UNRTDG class 4.3 PG I.
It ignites by contact with waters. (mixed touch hazardous Hb (2nd edition, 1997) p420)

Name: barium
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 2
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases
Rationale for classification: UNRTDG Class: 4.3; PG II

Name: Calcium acetylide
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Classification not possible (Category 1 or Category 2)
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Since reaction with water changes by the purity, particle form, and particle diameter of a sample, a given study is carried out and it will be classified into one of the followings. As a result of an examination, the sample with the tendency of reacting violently with the water and generating gas to ignite spontaneously or with the flammable/combustible gas generating speed of 10L/minute/kg or higher (equivalent to PG I) is classified into category 1, and the sample with the tendency of reacting rapidly with the water and indicating spontaneous combustibility but with the flammable/combustible gas generating speed that is under 10L/minute/kg and is 20L/hour/kg or higher (equivalent to PG II) is classified into category 2.

Name: lithium hydride
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: Category 1 UNRTDG Class:  4.3, PG I

Name: Phosphorous trichloride
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Category 1
Hazard statement: In contact with water releases flammable gases which may ignite spontaneously
Rationale for classification: It is based on the statement that it is reacts violently with water, generates inflammable Phosphine with fever, and has the possibility of fire and explosion (NFPA (13th, 2002)), and accompanied by generating of a diphosphan with ignitability (Bretheric (J) (5th, 1998)).

Name: Arsenic acid
Classification: Substances and mixtures, which in contact with water, emit flammable gases - Not classified (aqueous solution)
Rationale for classification: Stable to water (arsenic acid is present only in aqueous solutions (Lide, 84th, 2003)).
